sub_title: Assistant Professor // Regional Knowledge and Innovation Ecosystems
summary:
I am excited to start a new stage in my academic career as Assistant Professor at the University of Twente.  Building on my design background, practice-based research and experience with creative forms of engagement, I will contribute to innovative teaching and research on sustainable innovations that bring together different forms of knowledge and expertise. I will do this using the lens of 'gluing', a conceptual  and methodological framework that I am currently developing as a critical and creative approach to transformations towards sustainable futures. 

Originally trained as an architect, I have urban planning experience (London), a PhD in sustainable development (Trinity College Dublin) and postdoctoral research expertise in urban resilience (University of Sheffield) and creative forms of civic engagement in smart cities (Utrecht University).

authors.headline: Assistant Professor // Regional Knowledge and Innovation Ecosystems

profile_positions.description: Really pleased to join the Department of Technology, Policy and Society, sections Science, Technology and Policy Studies and Centre for Higher Education Policy Studies, at the University of Twente. Here, I will contribute to developing the Sustainable Rurban (rural-urban) Innovations platform, and challenge-based education programmes, with a focus on citizen science and sustainable development goals (SDGs).
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: Working with Michiel de Lange on the NWO project, "Designing for Controversies in Responsible Smart Cities" (https://www.nwo.nl/en/research-and-results/research-projects/i/66/30566.html). I will contribute to a multi-stakeholder collaboration platform aimed at achieving responsible smart cities. My work will focus specifically on urban datafication and civic engagement through creative methods. The project is a collaboration between Utrecht University and Twente University.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: Visiting fellow at the Interdisciplinary Centre of the Social Sciences (ICOSS) working with Professor Doina Petrescu on an urban resilience project (Sheffield School of Architecture / atelier d'architecture autogérée).
profile_positions.title: ICOSS Visiting Fellow

company.name: University of Reading / Lancaster University DEMAND Centre

profile_positions.company: University of Reading / Lancaster University DEMAND Centre
profile_positions.description: Collaboration on Theme 1 of the DEMAND research project - Trends and patterns in energy demand. My contribution is in relation to the geographic visualisation of time use data with the aim to improve the understanding of the implications of people’s energy consuming activities, whether at home, on the move, or at work.
profile_positions.title: Data Fellow

profile_positions.description:
In my PhD research, I examined the relationship between city inhabitants, decision-makers and their cities, and the potential role of digital technologies in enhancing this relationship. Moreover, I identified barriers to a more sustainable city and explored potential solutions. Building on an experimental and multi-layered study conducted in Dublin, Ireland, which employed a dynamic everyday mobility lens and included quantitative, qualitative and spatial methods, I proposed a conceptual map-based interactive platform entitled ‘Urban Spacebook’. The platform offers a framework and also examples of tools that can facilitate the creation of alternative spaces for engagement between city inhabitants and city decision-makers. Reflecting the collaborative process through which it emerged, the platform allows inhabitants to be involved not only in data generation (as emphasized in many citizen-sensing initiatives), but also in the co-production of knowledge about current urban spaces and their future development.

I presented my work at a number of international conferences:

• Global Conference on Mobility Futures, 4 - 6 September 2013, Lancaster University, UK.
• Governing Mobilities (joint conference of Mobilités spatiales et fluidité sociale – MSFS – and the Cosmobilities Network), 30 October - 1 November 2012, EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland.
• Local and Mobile: linking mobilities, mobile communication and locative media (the 3rd joint international conference of the Pan-American Mobilities Network and the Cosmobilities Network), 16-18 March 2012, NC State University, Raleigh, North Carolina.

The project is trans-disciplinary, at the exciting crossroads of urban studies, mobilities research and locative media art. It was selected for Interactivos?'12 Dublin Workshop - Dublin Hack the City Exhibition 2012. More at: http://mobilecityscapes.wordpress.com/ and https://www.facebook.com/InfiniteCity12
profile_positions.title: PhD

profile_positions.description: As part of their coursework, Senior Freshman Engineering students were given the task of designing and building portable structures (a refugee shelter, a homeless shelter and a play structure). The demonstrators’ involvement consisted in providing guidance to the students during the design and construction process.
profile_positions.title: Demonstrator, 2nd Year Engineering Design Module

profile_positions.description:
I was part of the organising team for the first annual Postgraduate Symposium on Sustainable Development 2011 (23-24 February, Dublin). The symposium was organised with the support of the Irish Research Council (former IRCSET / IRCHSS) and the Environmental Protection Agency of Ireland (EPAI). This was the first of a series of annual events which are aimed at bringing together postgraduate researchers from a broad spectrum of disciplinary backgrounds interested in the major challenges posed by achieving sustainable development. The key-note speakers included: Prof
Frank Convery (UCD), Prof Peter Söderbaum (Mälardalen University, Sweden) and Dr Ishwaran Natarajan (UNESCO, France).
profile_positions.title: Organiser, Postgraduate Symposium on Sustainable Development

profile_positions.description: I worked on projects for medium to large-scale office buildings, both new and refurbishments. I was involved in all project stages, from preliminary design to tender and construction stages. Software used: AutoCAD, Photoshop, Office Word and Excel.
profile_positions.title: Architect

profile_positions.description: I worked on projects for residential accommodation, including extensions to existing houses and small-scale new apartment developments. I was involved in preliminary design and planning application stages. Free hand sketching, AutoCAD and Photoshop.
profile_positions.title: Graduate Architect

profile_positions.description: I worked on an architectural competition for the regeneration of the industrial area of Cornigliano, Genoa, which informed my graduation thesis. My responsibilities included working on the concept, drawings and final presentation, using AutoCAD, Artlantis Render and Photoshop.
profile_positions.title: Architectural Assistant
